title: Magazine cover fonts
content:
Does anyone know the name of the fonts the words “Egg” and “Popteen” are written in?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/pic_ll_leute_bewild3_5953.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/cover_6638.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/pop2_4556.jpg)
author: blush.

comments.content: egg is gill sans ultra bold. popteen, i dunno, but that’s insaaaaaaaaaaaane.
Yaaay! Thanks! And I’ve uploaded a more clear version of the Popteen font if that helps.

I love the magazine covers you uploaded.

There’s a Japanese bookstore in downtown LA I go to that has these magazines. Its funny- there is a Tokyo scene fascinated by black american music and culture, a fascination that leads many to even put on blackface or a really dark tan and crimped and weaved hair. But I guess that’s okay- I’m obsessed with Japanese stuff. Kawaii stuff- I love your icon BTW.

Mikey :-)
ah, it is cooper. i couldn’t tell through all the fairy dust.

Haha. Same here Super! And thanks! And those girls are called ganguro.

I have 2 more magazine covers. Sorry to bother you all but I see no point in making a separate topic.

What are the fonts that “girl”, “Cawaii” and

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/woofin_cover_2_5506.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/20070518720_3433.jpg)

Girl is a customized Helvetica Compressed/Inserat/whatever.

_Woofin’_ Girl? :^D Is this a case of [Engrish](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331/http:/www.engrish.com/)?

Maybe we’re just not up on the latest lingo. Maybe “woofin’” is meant to be ironic like “brick shithouse”, e.g.: That girl be woofin’, homes. Or maybe it’s a reference to the loyalty of dogs: Why you checkin’ out my girl, bro? She’s woofin’ wit’ me now. Or maybe it has to do with listening to Snoop Doggy Dogg: Q: What are you listening to?
A: I’m woofin’. Which brings me to the concept of speakers - there’s tweeters and woofers. Maybe “woofin’” means “having a bass-like quality”: That beat be woofin’, homes. - Lex

Oh my... this is really something.

In the Cawaii image, Anniversary is in the luscious Bickham Script: [http://www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1736.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1736.html "http://www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P\_1736.html")

The sans is our good friend ITC Avant Garde Gothic Book: [http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/itc\_avant\_garde\_gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/itc_avant_garde_gothic/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/itc\_avant\_garde\_gothic/")

The script 3 and the ampersand aren’t Bickham, I don’t think... will have to check.

No, Woofin’ is a Japanese Urban magazine. This is the version geared towards females so that’s why it says Girl. (Like American magazine VIBE and then there is a female version of VIBE called VIBE Vixen which isn’t any sort of slang, it’s just the name of a magazine) It features more fashion and makeup, etc. Woofin’ is not any sort of new slang as the original Woofin’ (which is still on sale) has been out for years now, and it certainly isn’t a reference to “brick shithouse” or Snoop Dogg. Don’t hurt your heads thinking too much into it.

On the Cawaii image I want to know what the big word “Cawaii” is written in. Not anything else because I have those in my comouter, but thanks for your help.

So does anyone know what the big “Cawaii” is written in?
GIRL is probably a Einhorn that has been serious modified! Have a look at Kari Pro and Sneakers Script too.
Cawaii looks familiar... I’m certain I’ve seen that before.

Girl looks like Schlager from Fountain too:

[http://www.fountain.nu/catalogue/schlager.asp](http://web.archive.org/web/20090731123331/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/schlager.asp "http://www.fountain.nu/catalogue/schlager.asp")

Mikey :-)
